direct_enhancements.reason: Both methods find elements based on a specific attribute (class vs. tag) but share similar traversal and filtering logic.
Both methods locate elements based on a unique identifier (class vs. ID) and use similar traversal mechanisms.
Both methods search for elements with a specific attribute (class vs. any attribute) and share similar traversal and filtering logic.
The select method can be used to achieve the same functionality as getElementsByClass using CSS selectors.
The select method with an Evaluator can be used to achieve the same functionality as getElementsByClass by customizing the evaluator.
Both methods search for elements with a specific attribute value (class vs. any attribute value) and share similar traversal and filtering logic.
Both methods search for elements based on attribute value conditions (class vs. not equal to a value) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods search for elements based on attribute value conditions (class vs. value starting with a prefix) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods search for elements based on attribute value conditions (class vs. value ending with a suffix) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods search for elements based on attribute value conditions (class vs. value containing a substring) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods search for elements based on attribute value conditions (class vs. value matching a pattern) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods search for elements based on attribute value conditions (class vs. value matching a regex) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods filter elements based on index conditions (class vs. index less than a value) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods filter elements based on index conditions (class vs. index greater than a value) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods filter elements based on index conditions (class vs. index equal to a value) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods search for elements containing specific text (class vs. text content) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods search for elements containing specific text (class vs. own text content) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods search for elements matching specific text patterns (class vs. text matching a pattern) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods search for elements matching specific text patterns (class vs. text matching a regex) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods search for elements matching specific text patterns (class vs. own text matching a pattern) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods search for elements matching specific text patterns (class vs. own text matching a regex) and share similar traversal logic.
Both methods collect elements but with different criteria (class vs. all elements) and share similar traversal logic.
